pull_request.title: Fix generating todo when todo file already exists
pull_request.body: Fixes #565 by not loading the `.standard_todo.yml` file when generating a new todo file.

commits.message: trap annoying warning output from tests

issue.title: Was indented_internal_methods considered?

labels.name: rule change 👩‍⚖️
labels.description: Suggest a style guide rule change

issue.body:
Hey folks 👋 

Quick question: Did the team already considered enforcing `Layout/IndentationConsistency` with `indented_internal_methods`? 

I know this is a polemic topic but I kind like the way `indented_internal_methods` https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/rubocop/RuboCop/Cop/Layout/IndentationConsistency works when navigating through the source code 😄 

```rb
# good
class A
  def test
    puts 'hello'
    puts 'world'
  end

  protected

    def foo
    end

  private

    def bar
    end
end
```

did standard ever considered this option or this is a definitely a non go? 

thanks a lot

comment.body:
amazing. thanks for answering it @searls 

agree with you

issue.title: Was indented_internal_methods considered?
issue.body:
Hey folks 👋 

Quick question: Did the team already considered enforcing `Layout/IndentationConsistency` with `indented_internal_methods`? 

I know this is a polemic topic but I kind like the way `indented_internal_methods` https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/rubocop/RuboCop/Cop/Layout/IndentationConsistency works when navigating through the source code 😄 

```rb
# good
class A
  def test
    puts 'hello'
    puts 'world'
  end

  protected

    def foo
    end

  private

    def bar
    end
end
```

did standard ever considered this option or this is a definitely a non go? 

thanks a lot

issue.title: Was indented_internal_methods considered?
issue.body:
Hey folks 👋 

Quick question: Did the team already considered enforcing `Layout/IndentationConsistency` with `indented_internal_methods`? 

I know this is a polemic topic but I kind like the way `indented_internal_methods` https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/rubocop/RuboCop/Cop/Layout/IndentationConsistency works when navigating through the source code 😄 

```rb
# good
class A
  def test
    puts 'hello'
    puts 'world'
  end

  protected

    def foo
    end

  private

    def bar
    end
end
```

did standard ever considered this option or this is a definitely a non go? 

thanks a lot

comment.body:
We did consider this rule when we first started work on Standard and decided against it.

The primary reason is that `public`/`protected`/`private` labels do not denote actual nested constructs (like classes, blocks, if-else/case statements, or method definitions) and therefore it isn't consistent to indent them as if they were.  They're really just class methods that mutate a class's state such that the specified modifier will be applied as the visibility to all subsequently-defined methods until another visibility modifier class method is invoked.

issue.title: Was indented_internal_methods considered?
issue.body:
Hey folks 👋 

Quick question: Did the team already considered enforcing `Layout/IndentationConsistency` with `indented_internal_methods`? 

I know this is a polemic topic but I kind like the way `indented_internal_methods` https://www.rubydoc.info/gems/rubocop/RuboCop/Cop/Layout/IndentationConsistency works when navigating through the source code 😄 

```rb
# good
class A
  def test
    puts 'hello'
    puts 'world'
  end

  protected

    def foo
    end

  private

    def bar
    end
end
```

did standard ever considered this option or this is a definitely a non go? 

thanks a lot

pull_request.title: Adds pre-commit hooks support
pull_request.body: Adds support for [pre-commit](https://pre-commit.com/) hooks management framework.

issue.title: Adds pre-commit hooks support
issue.body: Adds support for [pre-commit](https://pre-commit.com/) hooks management framework.

comment.body:
I'm sorry, but I'm :-1: on this practice as well as this implementation.

* Team-wide enforcement of pre-commit hooks that can be used to prevent commits until issues are resolved will, in practice, often have the effect of delaying people from "saving their work," elongating feedback loops (which we should strive to make fast) and delaying the integration of code (which we should strive to make continuous). I've seen them used extensively in a number of environments over the years, and in a majority of cases they were instituted by—hate to be frank here—tech leaders with an authoritarian bent and imposed on others who weren't given a choice in the matter but to run them (robbing them of a sense of agency and autonomy over how they work).
* Open source "meta tools" like [pre-commit](https://pre-commit.com) typified by requiring every other tool on the planet to commit a configuration file are, in my opinion, fundamentally flawed in their design. If I were building a tool like pre-commit, I wouldn't  bottleneck my tool's adoption around whether users are successful in lobbying or pressuring other open sources to shove my specialized configuration file into their dotfile junk drawer. Instead, I'd design a community-managed repository as a fallback (like [tapioca does with Sorbet typings](https://github.com/Shopify/rbi-central)) or a decentralized way for users to author and share their own configurations that target specific tools

For these reasons, I'm personally opposed to tools of this sort in the absence of an overwhelmingly clear value proposition.

issue.title: Adds pre-commit hooks support
issue.body: Adds support for [pre-commit](https://pre-commit.com/) hooks management framework.

comment.body: @searls Would it be possible to get your eyes on this? Having an "official" support for `standardrb` with a pre-commit hooks framework would be nice. Thanks!

issue.title: VSCode is giving me StandardRb issues (expected) and Rubocop issues (unexpected)
issue.body:
I have removed Rubocop from my project and added StandardRb.  I can have VSCode lint my files (and correct them) and it works as expected, but then moments later (sometimes 20 seconds, other times a couple minutes later) it will start reporting Rubocop issues that conflict with the StandardRb rules.  Any idea how to get VSCode to just use StandardRb and ignore Rubocop?

I have searched the repo for anything rubocop and turned it off, but still no luck.

This is my `.standard.yml`

```
ruby_version: 3.2

plugins:
  - standard-rails
```

My gemfile has the following:

```
gem "standard", group: [:development, :test]
gem "standard-rails", group: [:development, :test]
```

In VSCode I have Ruby LSP installed and StandardRb.  I do not have any Rubocop extensions install.  Very frustrated. :) 

Edit:

One clear example is double quotes vs single quotes.  StandardRb gives me double quotes, but then I get an error that is should be single quotes.

comment.body: For anyone else who finds this issue, the quick fix for Ruby LSP is to open its Extension Settings... "Edit in settings.json" the list of enabled LSP features... Set "diagnostics" to "false" and save.

pull_request.title: Fix order of arguments in `Standard::Base` test assertions
pull_request.body:
This is a minor fix to these tests to make failing test output easier to diagnose. Currently when these tests fail the "actual" and "expected" output are inverted.

I noticed this while working on a lint roller plugin that was a fork of `standard-custom` (where this issue also exists).

commits.message: fix order of arguments in base test assertions

Merge pull request #584 from jackjennings/criticaljack/fix-base-expect

Fix order of arguments in `Standard::Base` test assertions
